title.rendered: Chile edges closer to making internet a public service

content.rendered:
After several years of debate, Chile is close to approving a bill to declare the internet a public service after a mixed committee of deputies and senators gave it the green light on Wednesday.

“Since we assumed the task of leading the undersecretary of telecommunications [Subtel], we have pushed this bill that seeks to make digital connectivity a basic right for all people,” telecommunications undersecretary Claudio Araya said in a press release.

The bill recognizes internet access as a basic service and allows for mechanisms such as subsidizing demand with universal service funds.

Last September, the senate rejected amendments to the bill, so a mixed committee was formed to resolve the differences that arose with the lower house.

The lower chamber had made 22 amendments, of which 10 were to be reformulated by the mixed committee.

Among the topics to be reviewed were the incorporation of neighborhood associations, cooperatives and municipalities that provide their services to end users, the principles of technological neutrality, the use of public infrastructure, multicarrier long distance calling services, the obligation to make the list of user complaints public, the terms of service, access of regulator Subtel to companies’ databases, the delivery of commercial reports and fines.

Most of the issues brought before the joint committee were agreed upon relatively quickly but debate on article 14 dragged on. “In recent weeks there has been very hard work specifically on article 14… which is very relevant for the executive because it allows us to enshrine the principle of technological convergence,” Araya said during the committee session.

After the vote, the bill was sent for final approval in the full lower chamber and the senate.

The initiative had been presented in 2018 but became especially relevant with the COVID-19 pandemic, when it made significant progress in the both chambers.
